Class DumbHashSet

  • java.lang.Object
    • DumbHashSet
  • public class DumbHashSet
extends java.lang.Object
    A really dumb hash set implementation just for Strings.
    You should use an array of 27 MyList (MyArrayList or MyLinkedList) objects as the collection of buckets.
    Any non-null String may be an element of this set.
    The hashing algorithm is as follows:
    bucket 0 is for Strings whose first character is 'a' or 'A'
    bucket 1 is for Strings whose first character is 'b' or 'B'
    bucket 2 is for Strings whose first character is 'c' or 'C'
    and so forth
    bucket 25 is for Strings whose first character is 'z' or 'Z'
    bucket 26 is for Strings whose first character is not an alphabetical character, or for the empty String
    Hints:

    char primitives can be subtracted from one another. So for a String s = "bobby", int first = s.toLowerCase().charAt(0) - 'a';
    will assign 1 to first.

    For the iterator, have another MyList instance variable. When iterator() is called, walk the entire set adding every element to this extra MyList. Then set up and return an iterator on this instance variable. (MyArrayList already has an iterator.) Be sure to invalidate this iterator support MyList if add or remove are called. I did this by setting the instance variable to null.

    Author:
    parks

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public boolean add​(java.lang.String s)
        Add an element to the set.
        Parameters:
        s - the element to add. If s is null, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown. If s is already a member of the set, nothing is done.
        Returns:
        true if this collection is changed as a result of this operation, false otherwise

      • remove

        public boolean remove​(java.lang.String s)
        Remove the given item from the set.
        Parameters:
        s - the element to be removed from the set. If s is null, an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown.
        Returns:
        true if the Set is changed as a result of this operation, false otherwise.

      • contains

        public boolean contains​(java.lang.String s)
        Verify that an item is or is not contained in the set. If s is null, an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        s - is the item to be verified as being in the set, or not
        Returns:
        true if s is in the set, false otherwise

      • size

        public int size()
        The number of elements in the set
        Returns:
        the number of elements in the set

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.String> iterator()
        Establish an iterator to walk the elements of the Set.
        Note that order is undefined for hash sets and hash maps, so whatever order is best for us is fine.
        This iterator will be invalidated if add or remove are called while it is operating.
        Returns:
        Iterator to walk the elements of this set
